source: Nigerian Federal Ministry of Health - Safe Motherhood Strategy & Clinical Protocols
notes: These guidelines should be validated with official Nigerian clinical guidelines documents. Based on Nigerian Medical Association standards and WHO Nigeria-specific recommendations.

systolic.description: Blood pressure ranges for Nigerian women (mmHg). Pregnancy-specific: systolic >140 or diastolic >90 indicates hypertension.

fasting.description: Fasting blood glucose in mg/dL. For pregnancy: >126 indicates diabetes risk.

bmi.description: BMI ranges. Note: Nigerian population may have slightly different optimal ranges, but WHO standards are generally applicable.

heart_rate.description: Resting heart rate (bpm). Pregnancy: may be slightly elevated (up to 110 bpm can be normal).

body_temperature.description: Body temperature in Celsius. >37.5°C indicates fever.

pregnancy.description: Risk score thresholds for pregnancy risk assessment. Based on P(High) probability from ML model.

hypertension.description: Hypertension thresholds. Nigerian guidelines align with international standards but may have population-specific considerations.

preeclampsia.description: Preeclampsia criteria: BP ≥140/90 + proteinuria. Nigerian guidelines emphasize early detection.

gestational_diabetes.description: Gestational diabetes screening thresholds (mg/dL). Nigerian guidelines follow WHO/IADPSG criteria.

immediate_actions: Seek immediate medical consultation at a registered healthcare facility
Contact your healthcare provider within 24-48 hours
Monitor vital signs daily (blood pressure, heart rate, temperature)
Consider hospitalization for close monitoring if advised by healthcare provider
nigerian_specific: Visit a registered Primary Healthcare Centre (PHC) or General Hospital
Ensure you have emergency contact numbers saved
Keep your National Health Insurance Scheme (NHIS) card accessible if enrolled
Inform family members about your high-risk status

immediate_actions: Schedule appointment with healthcare provider within 1-2 weeks
Monitor vital signs regularly (2-3 times per week)
Maintain healthy diet rich in local Nigerian foods (vegetables, fruits, lean proteins)
Reduce stress and get adequate rest (7-9 hours sleep)
nigerian_specific: Continue regular antenatal care visits at your PHC or hospital
Follow traditional dietary practices that are safe during pregnancy
Stay hydrated, especially in hot weather
Avoid self-medication with traditional herbs without consulting healthcare provider

immediate_actions: Continue regular prenatal checkups as scheduled
Report any unusual symptoms immediately to healthcare provider
nigerian_specific: Attend all scheduled antenatal care visits
Follow balanced diet with local foods (yam, plantain, vegetables, fish)
Practice good hygiene to prevent infections common in Nigeria

pregnancy.third_trimester: Every 2 weeks until 36 weeks, then weekly
pregnancy.high_risk: As determined by healthcare provider (may be more frequent)

blood_sugar.high_risk: Earlier screening at 16-18 weeks, repeat at 24-28 weeks

nigerian_healthcare_context.primary_care: Primary Healthcare Centres (PHCs) are the first point of contact
nigerian_healthcare_context.tertiary_care: Teaching Hospitals and Federal Medical Centres
nigerian_healthcare_context.emergency_services: Call 112 (National Emergency Number) or local emergency services
nigerian_healthcare_context.health_insurance: National Health Insurance Scheme (NHIS) provides coverage for many services
nigerian_healthcare_context.traditional_medicine: Many women use traditional medicine alongside modern care - important to discuss with healthcare provider
nigerian_healthcare_context.cultural_considerations: Respect for traditional practices while ensuring evidence-based care

population_specific_notes.blood_pressure: Nigerian women may have slightly different baseline BP patterns. Some studies suggest slightly higher normal ranges, but international standards (120/80) are generally applicable.
population_specific_notes.bmi: Nigerian population may have different body composition. BMI thresholds are generally applicable but should be interpreted with clinical context.
population_specific_notes.diabetes: Diabetes prevalence in Nigeria is increasing. Gestational diabetes screening is critical, especially in urban areas.
population_specific_notes.anemia: High prevalence of anemia in Nigerian women. Iron supplementation is often recommended.
population_specific_notes.malaria: Malaria is endemic in Nigeria. Pregnant women should use insecticide-treated nets and take prophylaxis as recommended.
